item.title: Biot-Savart Law
item.description: A fundamental aspect of the concept of Electromagnetism is that a moving electric field creates a magnetic field. The direction of a field follows the right hand rule, with the velocity being the thumbs and the fingers being the magnetic field.

item.title: Common Cases of Ampère's Law
item.description: Distance r away from an infinitely long wire B = \frac{\mu_{0}I}{2 \pi r} Inside a Solenoid with n turns per unit length B = \mu_{0}nIInside a toroidal Solenoid with total N turns B = ...

item.title: EMF
item.description: Electromotive force (EMF) is an energy transfer to an electric circuit per unit of electric charge, measured in volts. It is not a force, and it would be more accurate to call it source voltage.

item.title: Ampère's Law With Maxwell's Addition
item.description: A complete form of Ampère’s Law. \nabla \times B = \mu_{0} (J + \epsilon_{0} \frac{\partial E}{\partial t}) \oint_{C} \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{l} = \mu_{0} (I + \epsilon_{0} \frac{d \Phi_{E}}{d t}) Connection between differential and integral form todo.

item.title: Faraday's Law
item.description: The EMF around a closed path is equal to the negative of the time rate of change of the magnetic Flux enclosed by the path. \mathcal{E} = -\frac{d \Phi_B}{dt} Accordingly, a Solenoid with N total turns will have an EMF N times as large as that induced by just one of its loops: \mathcal{E} = -N\frac{d \Phi_B}{dt} Of a rotating loop with N total turns and angular velocity \omega: \mathcal{E} = -N\frac{d \Phi_{B}}{dt} = NBA \omega sin(\omega t) Stationary Faraday’s Law If the path is stationary: \oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{l} = -\frac{d \Phi_B}{dt} Inside a Solenoid: \oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{l} = -\frac{dB}{dt}A = -\mu_{0}n \frac{dI}{dt} A.

item.title: Flux
item.description: The result of a surface integral, e.g. \Phi = \iint \vec{F} \cdot d \vec{S} Perpendicular-flowiness of the vector field through the surface.

item.title: Inductor
item.description: A Solenoid. Inductors resist change in current. Inductors have a property called Inductance. A good analogy for an inductor is a flywheel, where angular inertia represents resistance to current change.

item.title: Maxwell-Faraday Equation
item.description: The differential form of this particular one of Maxwell’s Equations. \nabla \times E = -\frac{\partial B}{\partial t} \mathcal{E} = \oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{l} = -\frac{d \Phi_{B}}{d t} = - \frac{d}{dt} \oiint_{S} \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{S} = - \oiint_{S} \frac{\partial B}{\partial t} \cdot d \vec{S} Also: Faraday’s Law.

item.title: Solenoid
item.description: A wire loop with turns in it. You get a magnetic field through one when current goes through it such that B \propto I. B =\mu_0nI.
